title: The bestselling Canadian books for the week of Aug. 31-Sept. 7, 2019 | CBC Books
text:
Here are the bestselling Canadian books for Aug. 31-Sept. 7, 2019.

Bestseller lists are compiled by Bookmanager using weekly sales stats from over 260 Canadian independent stores.

Louise Penny is the author of A Better Man. (Jean-François Bérubé, Raincoast Books)

A Better Man by Louise Penny is the #1 Canadian fiction book this week.

In A Better Man, Armand Gamache is reinstated as head of the homicide department in Quebec just as the province is hit with a flooding crisis. In the midst of chaos, a father begs Gamache to help find his missing daughter, a case that draws intense public scrutiny.

See the full Canadian fiction list below.

The Wake is a nonfiction book by Linden MacIntyre. (Joe Passaretti, HarperCollins Canada)

The Wake by Linden MacIntyre is the #1 Canadian nonfiction book this week.

In 1928, St. Lawrence, N.L. was devastated by a tsunami that left 28 dead and hundreds more injured or homeless. Following the disaster, the village's economy transitioned from fishing to mining, but it was discovered that the underground mine was radioactive and killed hundreds of miners. The Wake tells the story of how one wave changed everything for an entire community.

See the full Canadian nonfiction list below.

Cherie Dimaline is the author of The Marrow Thieves. (Peter Power/CBC, Dancing Cat Books)

The Marrow Thieves by Cherie Dimaline is the #1 Canadian kids book this week.

In the dystopian world of The Marrow Thieves, climate change has ravaged the Earth and a continent-wide hunt and slaughter of Indigenous people is underway. Wanted for their bone marrow, which contains the lost ability to dream, a group of Indigenous people seek refuge in the old lands.

See the full Canadian kids book list below.
